results.title: Miquette et Sa Mere = Miquette and Her Mother
results.brief_description:
Miquette aspires to be an actress. She runs off with a nobleman who promises to make her a star. When Miquette’s mother searches for her wandering daughter, she finds the girl working with a ragtag touring company. The mother takes a job with the troupe to keep the lecherous nobleman away from Miquette. The film works best as a portrait of a provincial theatre in the 19th century.

Credits: Producer, Paul Joly ; director, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writer, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Albert Lasry ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Bourvil, Daniele Delorme, Mireille Perrey, Saturnin Fabre, Pauline Carton, Paul Barge, Leonce Corne, Jeanne Fusier-Gir, Olivier Hussenot, Philippe Nicaud, Pierre Olaf, Maurice Schutz, Louis Seigner.

results.title: Aida
results.creator_credit: Pierre Jourdan, Daniele Gegauff and Stephane Tchalgadjieff
results.brief_description:
This version of Verdi’s ‘Aida’ was recorded at the antique theatre of Orange (France). The stage direction is by Sandro Segui, decors by Pier-Luigi Pizi and choreography by Jacques Garnier. The Orchestra ‘Lirico di Torino’ is conducted by Thomas Schippers.

Credits: Cast: Producers, Stephane Tchalgadjieff, Daniele Gegauff ; director, Pierre Jourdan ; photography, Jean-Pierre Lazar.
Cast: Gilda Cruz-Romo, Grace Bumbry, Peter Gougalov.

results.title: Qui? = Who?
results.brief_description:
A car rides off a cliff. The female passenger survives the ordeal, her male companion, the driver does not. The brother of the dead man takes the young woman back to his place. Although he suspects her to have something to do with his brother’s death, he is inexplicably attracted to her. The police recovers the dead body and for a while the suspicions a laid to rest. But the ‘dead man’ reappears not long after Â…

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Leonard Keigel ; writers, Leonard Keigel, Paul Gegauff ; photography, Jean Bourgoin ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Romy Schneider, Maurice Ronet, Simone Bach, Jacques Duby, Gabriele Tinti.

results.title: Pile Ou Face = Heads or Tails
results.brief_description:
Edouard Morlaix’s wife dies after falling through a window. Inspector Baroni is convinced she was pushed by Morlaix who wanted to be free to run away with his mistress. Baroni starts harrassing Morlaix in the hope to have him break down and admit to the murder.

Credits: Producer, Georges Cravenne ; director, Robert Enrico ; writers, Robert Enrico, Michel Audiard, Marcel Jullian ; photography, Didier Tarot ; music, Lino Leonardi.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Michel Serrault, Dorothee, Pierre Arditi, Andre Falcon, Fred Personne, Jean Desailly.

results.title: Suivez-Moi Jeune Homme! = Follow Me Young Man!
results.creator_credit: Guy Le Franc, Marcel Lathiere and Paul Cadeac
results.brief_description:
Oranos, a wealthy greek business man, is in love with Francoise, a jewellery shop attendant, who consistantly rebuffs him. Suspecting she may already have a boyfriend, he is having her followed by Michel, a private detective, who promptly falls in love with her.

Credits: Producer, Paul Cadeac, Marcel Lathiere ; director, Guy Le Franc ; writers, Roland Moronval, Jean Halain ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Louiguy.
Cast: Dany Robin, Daniel Gelin, Lona Rita, Jacques Jouanneau, Noel Roquevert, Georges Chamarat, Michel Galabru, Fernand Sardoux.

results.title: Le Vol D'icare (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
Icare is the creation of a famous Parisian writer. While his master is otherwise engaged with an afternoon ‘rendez-vous’, Icare slips off the page and into the street. The writer suspecting that Icare’s flight is in fact the result of plagiarism engages dectective Morcol to try and locate the runaway hero.

Credits: Director, writer, Daniel Ceccaldi ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Michel Galabru, Caroline Cellier, Henri Garcin, Evelyne Buyle, Roger Carel, Piere Mallet.

results.title: Tu Seras Terriblement Gentille = You'll Be Awfully Nice
results.creator_credit: Dirk Sanders, Louis Duchesne and Rene Thevenet
results.brief_description:
Clara and Patrice decide to separate. Filled with ambition, Patrice goes to Paris to work as a photographer. Clara obtains custody of their daughter Julie. Although Clara and Julie remain without news from Patrice for years, the little girl has not lost hope of seeing her parents getting back together. One day, they decide to travel to Paris …

Credits: Producer, Louis Duchesne, Rene Thevenet ; director, Dirk Sanders ; writers, Dirk Sanders, Paul Soreze ; photography, Roger Duculot ; music, Jacques Loussier.
Cast: Frederic de Pasquale, Karen Blanguernon, Leslie Bedos, Jean Moussy, Victor Moussy.

results.title: Le retour de Surcouf = Cyclone on the Indian Ocean (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
The British have taken hold of Mahe, a French possession in the Indian Ocean. Surcouf is sent to rescue secrets documents detailing the whole French military set up in the region before it falls into ennemy hands.

Credits: Director, Sergio Bergonzelli ; writers, Jacques Severac, George de la Giraudiere, J. A. de la Loma ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Gerard Barray, Antonella Lualdi, Genevieve Casile.

results.title: L'amour Fou = Mad Love
results.creator_credit: Jacques Rivette and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
“Rightly described by Dave Kehr as Jacques Rivette’s ‘breakthrough film, the first of his features to employ extreme length (252 minutes), a high degree of improvisation, and a formal contrast between film and theater,’ this rarely screened 1968 masterpiece is one of the great French films of the 60s. It centers on rehearsals for a production of Racine’s Andromaque and the doomed yet passionate relationship between a director and his actress wife, who leaves the production at the beginning of the film and then festers in paranoid isolation. The rehearsals, filmed by Rivette (in 35-millimeter) and by TV documentarist Andre S. Labarthe (in 16mm), are real, and the relationship between Kalfon and Ogier is fictional, but this only begins to describe the powerful interfacing of life and art that takes place over the film’s hypnotic, epic unfolding. In the rehearsal space Rivette cuts frequently between the 35- and 16-millimeter footage, juxtaposing two kinds of documentary reality; in the couple’s apartment, filmed only in 35, the oscillation between love and madness, passion and mistrust, builds to several terrifying and awesome climaxes in which the distinctions between life and theater, reality and fiction, become virtually irrelevant. In many ways this is Ogier’s richest, finest performance, and Kalfon keeps pace with her every step of the way. This film captures the dreams and desperation of the 60s like few others, and you emerge from it changed; it’s a life experience as much as a film experience. Rivette’s obsessional uses of real time and natural duration take some getting used to, but the experience becomes both mesmerizing and all-enveloping.” Reference: Jonathan Rosenbaum. Chicago Reader. Online. http://onfilm.chireader.com/

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jacques Rivette ; writers, Jacques Rivette, Marilu Parolini ; photography, Etienne Becker, Alain Levent ; music, Jean-Claude Eloy.
Cast: Bulle Ogier, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Josee Destoop, Celia, Andre S.-Labarthe.

results.title: Strictement Personnel = Strictly Private
results.brief_description:
Jean Cottard lives in Lyons where he works as a police officer. He occupies his leisure time with writing. Called to Paris by his publisher, Jean uses the opportunity to visit his relatives. To his great surprise, he discovers they are all involved in criminal activities. Little by little, he learns that his father has become an expert forger, his brother is a drug addict while his stepmother is works as a prostitute. Things get worse. Jean’s stepmother is murdered aboard the train that was meant to take him back to Lyons. As Jean investigates the murder, he realises just how personnal this affair is.

Credits: Producers, Simone Benzakien, Pierre Jolivet ; director, Pierre Jolivet ; writer, Pierre Jolivet ; photography, Christian Lamarque ; music, Serge Perathoner.
Cast: Pierre Arditi, Jacques Penot, Caroline Chaniolleau, Jean Reno, Robert Rimbaud, Jean Bouise.
